data.text: What Are the Essential Bike Spares for Touring Long Distances?
I‚Äôm planning our first big tour for next year (7 - 8,000 km) and hoping to keep our gear as light as possible. But specifically what bike spares do people generally consider essential?
Tubes, some multitool, air pump or co2 cartridge.
data.author: Daniel Dziku Zalewski

data.text: Credit card.
data.author: Tobi Schmidtn√∂r

data.text: Essential in western Europe and essential in the desert are two very different concepts. Where are you going?
data.author: Wilhelm Mellerg√•rd

data.text: good point - I‚Äôll give you one guess!
data.author: Snails around France

data.text: Snails around France could it be France? Because if it's France, then a new consideration comes into play. One which would require just as many supplies as the desert, maybe even more. Do you intend to cycle on sundays?
data.author: Wilhelm Mellerg√•rd

data.text: yes üòÇ
data.author: Snails around France

data.text: Snails around France you shall require extra spokes, cabling, brake pads, backup chain, spare derailleur hangers, a bike stand, a complete set of tools, and some extra tyres. Or, if you are prepared to wait for the monday if you run into bike trouble on a sunday, you'll be fine with a multitool and your preferred supplies for fixing a flat.
data.author: Wilhelm Mellerg√•rd

data.text: excellent
data.author: Snails around France

data.text: Puncture kit and a multi tool with a chain breaker..
data.author: Julian Wells

data.text: nuts and bolts, brake cable, zip ties, spokes...
data.author: Simon Wilson

data.text: I always wondered to what extent one would need to practice spoke replacement before. The tutorials I've read online quickly descend into full-fledged wheel building.
data.author: Matthias Tango

data.text: No I usually take two or three taped to the frame, weigh very little and had to replace one in Iceland once. No wheel rebuilds thankfully. Spoke key always handy though and a little practice in the garden to ensure you have the technique down.
data.author: Simon Wilson

data.text: In Europe: Tube, puncture repair kit, quicklink for chain. Multi-tool with chain breaker, pump. Even if you bust your derailleur, you can fix the bike so it runs on one gear (crack chain, shorten it, quick link) until you get to the next town. If you break a spoke you can usually travel carefuly for many kilometers.. If you break a wheel, you are pretty much stuck, until you can get to a bikeshop.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Addendum. Although that is perhaps the bare minimum, I confess that I carry more üòÅ
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: You can get parts shipped to almost anywhere in the world now, ordered from your phone. Take only a spare tube and maybe a foldable tire.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: OK if you have the time to wait for the stuff to to arrive.

data.text: yes, that would be a problem
data.author: Snails around France

data.text: Something that hasn't been mentioned is a rear mech hanger. It's specific to a bike model and damaging it can cause real probs when on the road. Always carry a spare.
data.author: Jon Belt

data.text: this
data.author: Ainis Baltakis

data.text: yes, something not to worry about if you have one - I‚Äôll be getting the bike serviced before we go - along with a shopping list!
data.author: Snails around France

data.text: Snails around France You really don‚Äôt need a rear hanger. 20K miles over 6 years of touring and the original is still fine. I‚Äôve switched out the jockey wheels once but otherwise the chances of the hanger itself breaking are slim to none.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: in France there are shops and bike shops. Spare tubes, puncture repair. Cable ties for stuff that moves that shouldn't, WD40 for the opposite. If you overload your bike don't be surprised if spokes go.
data.author: Gill Brown

data.text: its normally if it gets knocked from an accident. You can go your whole life without needing a spare but if you do when you're on the road it could easily set u back a week or much more. Its light and cheap so worth it. More important off road of course.
data.author: Jon Belt

data.text: I did have one fail on me 6 months into my Giant carbon road bike.

data.text: ‚ÄúCable ties for stuff that moves that shouldn't, WD40 for the opposite‚Äù. Love that üòä

data.author: Jan Ayalin

data.text: I broke mine by changing the chain myself and a bit I didn‚Äôt completely have in line hit the rear hanger and took it off
data.author: Sarah Dunford

data.text: I would add a small screwdriver with interchangeable heads. Just to tighten up those things like racks that can rattle loose.
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: -Nuts and bolts assortment (consider some threadlocker too). -Derailleur hanger. -if tubeless, new valves. -Puncture repair kit for your tire type (patches, plugs, inner tube(s) or sealant, boot) -Spare tires (depending on your route) -Duct tape straps and zip ties. -Chain link (more than 1). -Tools (multitool with a chain breaker, pump, levers, oil, rag, pliers). In regards to other answers indicating that all you need is a credit card and that you can order anywhere: it's false. Outside Western Europe or North America, it can be complicated, expensive, or impossible.
data.author: Elie BD

data.text: really useful list there, thanks.
data.author: Snails around France

data.text: this^ Try getting anything shipped to Bosnia. No online shop will ship there as they are in the naughty corner for some reason. Try getting anything over 150euro value shipped to Turkey, customs will be 7-9 weeks. OK, Turkey has a couple of well stocked online shops I‚Äôll get my part there....... erm, try using a foreign credit card online to a Turkish business from within Turkey. OK, I‚Äôll just use Paypal -bzzz, doesn‚Äôt exist in Turkey. Then I‚Äôll do a direct deposit to the store bank account, erm not possible for non-Turkish citizens..... just examples of 2 countries, just remember - you‚Äôre not always in Kansas. The idea that all you have to do is hitch a ride to the next town and then just pay is a fallacy. There will be plenty of good suggestions here but one that may not come up....... what if your pump fails??? Yep, I carry a spare pump! For 2 people I carry a spare set of pedals (cable tied to rack), a spare tyre, 4 tubes, 3 drive side and 3 non-drive side spokes and nipples, 2 gear cables, a rear mech hanger ( we both have the same frame), 2 spare chain joiners/ quick links, 4 sets of disk pads. Essential tools. Multi tool that you know and trust that includes a chain breaker, full size long series allen keys up to 6mm, leatherman tool, spoke key, cassette removal tool, 8mm hex t-bar, chain gauge, patches n glue, assorted and appropriate screws, washers, nuts, cable ties, electrical tape, chain lube..... erm, etc. current trip - a bit over 12000km‚Äôs. have used the spare pedals for 2 days, have used one of the 2 gear cables, have changed brake pads at about 3500km intervals, used say 15 patches, 3 bottles of chain lube, have replaced chains once and my cassette/ chainrings. Think about what will stop you dead and what you could McGuiver your way out of. ( and then halve it). üôÇ
data.author: Craig Pullen

data.text: Please, read carefully, I agree with you. P.S. I am not in Kansas üòä

data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: When one heads off one should service he's bike 200% new chain new tyres break pads wear and tear should be changed.double check for cracks etc etc. Then you should be fine. 99% anyway. your frame or fork cracks it's game over anyway.
data.author: Thomas Heaney

data.text: Thomas Heaney Of course, departure has to be with a bike as perfect as possible. Any issue during the trip will cost more to solve and waste precious time.
data.author: Elie BD

data.text: Multitool, spare tube, pump, cable ties and as mentioned Credit card. Schwalbe Marathon Plus Performance tyre and you'll not puntucure in western Europe. the things are rock solid
data.author: Thomas Heaney

data.text: sorry, entering this thread: I have newly had a problem with my Schwalbe Marathon plus front tire due to a little bike accident. Though the fender was pressed against the tire and some rubber was scrabed off until I came to the next village, where I have got help. Do you think I need a new tire?
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: if it was the side wall yes I'd recommend getting a new one. Really depends on how much was taken off. Ok I personally would get a new tyre. you don't want to be stuck out in the middle of nowhere when it bursts. cost's maybe 40‚Ç¨ in Europe, Save yourself a lot of hassle in the long run. Your next bike retailer. drop in and ask for he's professional opinion.
data.author: Thomas Heaney

data.text: Thanks for your answer.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Don't carry anything you don't know how to use.

data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: My tool kit consist of: One tube, a patch kit, spoke wrench, fiber fix spoke, pedros, two spare chain links, a lightweight chain breaker, a small multi tool, and some gorilla tape wrapped around a straw. Anything else is overkill IMO.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I took a smallish kit around Europe for 8 weeks. Puncture Repair kit Spare inner tube. Multi tool including pliers Small wrench Chain breaker Spare Chain 1 set of brake blocks. Duck tape Oil. 1 brake cable 1 gear cable. I managed fine dealt with all mechanicals including snapped chain.

data.author: Sandra Peters

data.text: Extra tube x2 Kit to patch tube Shifter cable Break cable (if not the same type) Breakpads A few nuts and bolts Zip ties Duck tape. Tools Pump Multitool Spoke key ‚Ä¶.. I really should bring some spare spokes but to replace them I would need to learn how to remove my discbreaks and casset. There is no point bringing stuff you don‚Äôt have the skills to use,
data.author: Per Sjunnesson

data.text: If it's within Europe & your bike's serviced before you start then just a spare tube & patches, albeit on my bike I use a Rohloff gearing so the only other spare I carry are brake cables & brake pad inserts, but over three extended tours have never used the cables, a small selection of nuts & botls, a few cable ties, some spare spokes fro font & rear wheels & a couple of metres of gaffa tape wrapped around a pen.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: 2 inner tube - 1 folding tyre - derailleur hanger - rear derailleur(remote place - sahara) Bike tools + chain tool + pump

data.text: From comments it looks like I carry least spares ü§î I only carry extra tube and tyre repair kit with pump. Then chain oil. That's all. Because what u carry is not what you end up needing, especially for me. Best spare part is patience to endure slowly until u find it.. I try to service my bike to my best capacity before trip and I go thousands of miles without issue
data.author: Kyagera Ivan

data.text: Sorry me again ü§£ my last tour I meet a guy and he had some spare spokes. really good idea. break one or two spokes in the back arse of nowhere can be really painful. something you don't break often but I'm definitely taking some with me on my next tour. Just tape them onto the frame somewhere. you won't even notice there there.
data.author: Thomas Heaney

data.text: Bike breakdown insurance that will at least take you to the nearest bike shop !! I have one (admittedly UK only) for ¬£25 a year.
data.author: Mark Sippings

data.text: Depends on your bike. For me, tools appropriate to bike... Alen keys, spokes, spoke key, multitool in pliers, spare gear cable, puncture repair kit, spare tubes, oil, rag, cable ties, insulation tape. Anything more complex go to a bike shop.

data.text: Don't start a tour on untested gear, bike or shoes.

data.text: around France
data.author: Snails around France

data.text: Snails around France As I read "light as possible", avoid spokes, chain opener, chain parts, the big 15mm wrench (verify your pedals, many adopt a hex key); Bring all the necessary for repair a puncture of course. Bring a multitool. Avoid big knifes, rambo style, or other metal tools. If you are not loading your racks substantially, do not bring spare rack parts. No need for carrying a spare tire, in France. That's about it; I left home for 80 days and across the USA. The only thing you'll repair are flat tires, normally. Some other problem may occur, but you are not crossing the mongolian deserts :D
data.author: Vlady Stroy
